thread.title: Retail sales slip for first time in 14 months
thread.title_full: Retail sales slip for first time in 14 months

title: Retail sales slip for first time in 14 months
text:
So you've bought it - but what happens if you discover it's 'not quite right'? Photo: Louie Douvis
Defence spending keeps economy growing Economic growth close to zero as living standards slip Retail sales fell 0.1 per cent in July, the first nationwide decline since May last year.
The data follows news that Australia's economy has slowed to a crawl, with annual growth of just 2 per cent.
Treasurer Joe Hockey struggled to explain on Wednesday why economic growth was so slow, and this soft retail sales figure will add to the sombre mood.
Advertisement Bureau of Statistics figures show there was an increase in spending on clothing, footwear and personal accessory retailing (2.9 per cent), department stores (1.3 per cent) and cafes, restaurants and takeaway food services (0.3 per cent), in seasonally adjusted terms.
Food retailing did not grow at all.
There were falls in household goods retailing (-1.9 per cent) and other retailing (-0.6 per cent) following rises in both industries in June.
Retail sales provide a useful update on consumer spending because retail volumes comprise over 30 per cent of consumption.
more to come...
